properties.Name: Departing Fort Clatsop
properties.Synopsis: The expedition begins the return journey.

properties.Name: Sauvie Island
properties.Synopsis: Clark explored the Willamette River while the expedition camped at Sauvie Island, making notes on local natives. Most groups residing in the Columbia's Sauvie Island region belonged to Upper-Chinookan language groups, including the Katlaminimin, Clatskanie, Cath-la-cum-up, Clâh-in-nata, Cath-lah-nah-qui-ah, and Cath-lah-cam-mah-tup. Both Lewis and Clark made extensive notes about the rich complexity of tribal cultures, such as different types of dwellings, clothing, and hairstyles. The expedition leaders also noted the extent to which indigenous peoples used natural materials—particularly native plants—to construct homes and trade with nearby tribes.

properties.Name: Walla Walla Indians
properties.Synopsis: Walla Walla Indians invite them to stay and provide guidance on the expedition.
properties.Secondary Source: Pinkham, Allen., Evans, Steven Ross, and Hoxie, Frederick E. Lewis and Clark among the Nez Perce : Strangers in the Land of the Nimiipuu. Ron Laycock Collection of Lewis and Clark Literature. Washburn, North Dakota: Dakota Institute Press of the Lewis & Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, 2013.

properties.Name: Camp Chopunnish
properties.Synopsis: The expedition retrieved their horses from the Nez Perce and remained in Cap Chopunnish until the snows on the Rocky Mountains allowed for passage.

properties.Name: Lewis' horse slips 40 feet
properties.Synopsis: The Bitterroot Mountains are a section of the Rocky Mountains that create the border between Idaho and Montana. They were an extreme challenge to the Expedition due to their size and formidable peaks. While crossing the Bitterroots, Lewis' horse slipped and they both fell 40 feet down a mountain. Luckily, they both survived to continue the journey home.

properties.Name: Travelers' Rest
properties.Synopsis: Having finally made it through the treacherous journey crossing Bitterroots, the expedition began the final part of their trek home. The group split up to explore different routes to the Missouri river, each thinking that they could find the faster route home. Clark went up towards Yellowstone with half of the expedition and Lewis continued on the Nez Perce route with the other half.  Sergeants Ordway and Pryor were given separate tasks with smaller units.  The Corps wouldn't be reunited until they reached the Missouri several weeks later.  Lewis and Clark must have had a lot of faith in their men to delegate so much responsibility.
properties.Secondary Source: Ambrose, Stephen E. Undaunted Courage: Meriwether Lewis, Thomas Jefferson, and the Opening of the American West. New York: Simon & Schuster, 1996, p. 375-376.

properties.Name: Seaman's Creek
properties.Synopsis: Proceeding according to a shortcut the expedition had learned from natives, Lewis discovered a creek and named it after his steadfast companion. Donald Jackson later uses this event to determine that the dog’s name was Seaman (rather than Scannon, as had been previously thought): "No person named Seaman is known to have been associated with the lives of either captain, and as a common term the word seems strangely nautical in view of its location. When it became necessary for Lewis and Clark to name a creek, river, or other geographical feature, they were predictably direct and simple in their choices...They usually went straight to the heart of the matter and chose a sound, reasonable name for the simplest of reasons: to commemorate a member or sponsor of the expedition...It occurred to me that the name might be a garbled version of Scannon’s Creek, in honor of the faithful dog. The dog had been with Lewis on that side trip, and no geographical feature had yet been named for him during the entire expedition. I consulted microcopies of the journals held by the American Philosophical Society, half suspecting I would find that Seaman’s Creek was actually Scannon’s Creek. What I learned instead was mildly startling. The stream was named Seaman’s Creek because the dog’s name was Seaman."

properties.Name: Up the Marais
properties.Synopsis: Leaving the rest of the party behind at Great Falls with Gass, Lewis took George Drouillard and Joseph and Reuben Field to explore the upper part of the Marais River.
properties.Secondary Source: Allen, John L. "Lewis and Clark on the Upper Missouri: Decision at the Marias."  Montana: The Magazine of Western History 21, no. 3 (July 1971).

properties.Name: Nathaniel Pryor's First Mission
properties.Synopsis: Nathaniel Pryor set off with two privates on his first mission to the Mandan villages.  He brought horses to trade for supplies, along with a letter to Hugh Heney of the North West Company.  The letter asked for Heney's assistance in incorporating the Sioux into the planned American commercial trading system centered in St. Louis.  The letter read in part "The ardent wish of our government has ever been to conciliate the esteem and secure the friendship of all the Savage nations within their territory by the exercise of every consistent and pacific measure in her power, applying those of coercion only in the last resort...but we are also positive that she will not long suffer her citizens to be deprived of the free navigation of the Missouri by a fiew comparatively feeble bands of Savages who may be so illy advised as to refuse her proffered friendship and continue their depridation on her citizens who may in future assend or decend that river."
properties.Secondary Source: Letters of the Lewis and Clark Expedition with Related Documents 1783-1854. Edited by Donald Jackson. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1978, p. 310.

properties.Name: Down the Yellowstone
properties.Synopsis: Clark sets off down the Yellowstone River.

properties.Name: Encounter with Blackfeet
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and his party encountered a band of Piegan Blackfeet near Two Medicine River.  When the Piegan stole some rifles during the night, Reuben Field gave chase and stabbed a man named Side Hill Calf.  The Piegan then tried to take the Americans' horses.  Lewis woke up and shot one of the Blackfeet in the stomach.  Future years would see bitter conflict between the Blackfeet and American settlers, but that had more to do with upheavals in the Plains economic system than any precedent set by this particular incident.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P.  Lewis and Clark Among the Indians.  Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, pp. 238-244.

properties.Name: Lewis is shot
properties.Synopsis: While hunting elk along the northeast bank of the Missouri River, Lewis was shot accidentally by one of his own men. The expedition had paused to hunt, with Lewis and Pierre Cruzatte setting off alone. Separated by a strand of willow trees, Cruzatte mistook Lewis, dressed in brown leather, for an elk and shot him in the right thigh and buttocks. Lewis immediately suspected that Cruzatte, who had notably poor eyesight, had accidentally fired upon him. When he called Cruzatte's name and received no response, Lewis grew concerned that the group was under attack by Indians. He hurried back to the canoes and alerted the rest of the expedition to arm themselves and find Cruzatte. The men returned quickly, having seen no Indians but discovered Cruzatte in the undergrowth. While Lewis and Gass dressed Lewis's wound, Cruzatte claimed not to have heard Lewis's cries. Lewis recorded in his journals that although he did not believe Cruzatte to have intentionally fired, he suspected that Cruzatte had hidden upon realizing that he had maimed an expedition leader, frightened of the consequences he might face.

properties.Name: Reunion Point
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark are finally reunited at the Missouri river, and begin the last leg of their 8,000 mile journey together.

properties.Name: Fort Mandan (return)
properties.Synopsis:
The expedition returns to Mandan village to find their 1804 fort burned down.  They part ways with Sacagawea and Charbonneau.  Clark later regrets not remunerating Sacagawea for her work.

The expedition returned to Mandan village to find that their 1804 fort had burnt to the ground. The cause remains unknown. While Lewis and Clark had continued their westward journey, the Mandan had been locked in conflict with other local tribes, including the Sioux. The Mandan were glad to see the expedition again, and send them gifts of corn, beans, and squash. Lewis and Clark parted ways with Sacagawea and Charbonneau—fittingly, the site of their first meeting. Clark later regretted not remunerating Sacagawea for her work; without her diplomatic, translation, and navigational skills, the expedition's success would have been jeopardized. That Sacagawea assisted the Corps of Discovery so extensively was a significant accomplishment. At the age of sixteen, she crossed the country with an infant on her back and provided the expedition with crucial support. Her establishment of contacts with indigenous peoples and contributions to the expedition's natural history remain salient aspects of American history.
properties.Secondary Source: Anderson, Irving W. "A Charbonneau Family Portrait," The American West, Vol. XVII, No. 2, Spring, 1980.

properties.Name: Finally Home
properties.Synopsis: After two years, four months, and ten days, the Corps finally arrives back in St. Louis with their expedition complete.
